issues.description: The problem specification and the template expect a public Farm.singFarmSong() method (UML and task text instruct implementing singFarmSong()), but the solution implementation provides a public method named playFarmSong() instead. This name mismatch between the solution and the problem/template is a structural inconsistency: a core API method expected by students/tests (singFarmSong) is implemented under a different name in the reference solution, which can confuse students and break automated checks or comparisons.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method name consistent across artifacts. Either rename the solution's public method playFarmSong() to singFarmSong() (recommended) or update the problem statement and template to use playFarmSong(). Prefer renaming the solution method to singFarmSong() so the reference implementation matches the exercise description and template API.

issues.description: The problem statement and template expect a public Farm method named singFarmSong() (task description and template Farm.java declare/ask for singFarmSong()), but the solution implementation exposes the same functionality under the name playFarmSong(). This mismatched identifier for the same conceptual operation (playing/singing the farm song) creates a mapping barrier: students and automated tests looking for singFarmSong() will not find the matching implementation in the solution, and students comparing template -> solution may be confused about which method they should implement or verify.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the solution's public method playFarmSong() to singFarmSong() (or add a public singFarmSong() wrapper that delegates to playFarmSong()). This aligns the solution with the problem statement and template, removing the naming mismatch and avoiding confusion for students and tests.
